Truth, Exploration and Open Science
Uncategorized
What is Open Science. What is science? How is it related to the truth of what is and ethics? Here’s a little bit of thought for you:

Open Science seems to be a return to fundamental principles of forces and possibility, and in the human domain – ethics. A mote of dust in the breeze knows precisely every force acting on it and thus dances in the light coming from an open window. For humanity, knowledge increases the range of possibilities and leads to new options of action. The truth of reality constrains all possibilities; this is vast, limited access to knowledge of fundamental truths of possibility constrains our available actions. Our ethical systems determine what of these possible actions to take. By expanding options, we can respond with more of our ethics intact – a proxy for a sort of wisdom.
Science creates knowledge of the space of possibility of action. We derive this knowledge by taking an empirical view of the world or an experiment and concluding causation through a series of logical steps. This abbreviated version of the scientific method is cut off from the initiating force, the hypothesis. A hypothesis brings human motive to expand the realm of the true possibilities and may derive from self-satisfaction through closing gaps in knowledge or hypotheses that the hypothesizer believes will be “useful,” sometimes split into fundamental and applied sciences.
Adding to the knowledge space of humanity, we create a more significant number of options for action in our reality bounded universe. Now that we know the relationship between matter and energy, we have the option to build nuclear reactors to solve the energy needs of humanity. Once we observed that putting seeds into the earth and watering them caused them to grow we were enabled the deductive observation of farming.
Open Science is the process where these hypotheses, observations as data, the process to derive them (by code or by convention) is easily accessible to others to replicate, review the methodology and conclusions. Open science brings the ethics of beauty into our world. Like observing the dance of thousands of dust motes in a beam of light, or a balanced ecosystem with all the forces at play bringing about an orchestra of action and reaction. Open Science can bring a faster and more accurate mapping of truth for anyone willing to participate. This expanded realm of possibility means we can act on our ethics with more dimensions of freedom. We may have kept the benefits of increased food production, energy production, highrises, antibiotics for the elite. It seems logical that experiments are being conducted today that only benefit the elite. Closed access / secret science goes against the desire of truth. What does truth desire? If we accept things are, and that truth is, then truth is truth and truth “desires” to be known, to fill its total shape as it does everywhere else. Consciousness (that which conducts science) seems to be a rare force in the universe in its ability to hide and lie. Open Science is not an ethic; it is an enabler of ethical actions through access to knowledge and options for behaviors.
Open Science puts consciousness into the service of beauty by theorizing, exploring, deducing, and sharing – creating space for ethics – creating space to dance.

Global Protest Movements and Gandhi
Personal, philosophy
A few weeks ago, in Paris, I nearly got caught up with The Extinction Rebellion protestors getting teargassed right outside my doorstep. The country my family is from, Iraq, has been having protests have been going for months now with over 500 people killed. Lebanon’s Martyrs square, while full of protesters, has thankfully seen fewer killed. The Extinction Rebellion grows louder. It’s been about 10 years since the Occupy Wall Street movement and the Arab Spring. In 2003, I remember being 18 years old and speaking in front of 3,000 people against the Iraqi invasion. Growing up in a college town, protests and demonstrations were commonplace, yet I’m wary of jumping into the crowd these days, especially when the crowd is angry.

Each of these movements has so much history and potential positive action, yet somehow I find myself unable to understand my responsibility towards them. Make your voice heard is the idea. As Desmond Tutu once said, “If you are neutral in situations of injustice, you have chosen the side of the oppressor.”

“We must always take sides. Neutrality helps the oppressor, never the victim. Silence encourages the tormentor, never the tormented. The opposite of love is not hate, itâ€™s indifference.”
â€” Elie Wiesel

There’s a word I’ve been struggling to identify. It describes a situation where the more effort you put into something, the more tangled up you become in it. That somehow, when you’re caught in barbed wire, it’s best to stop moving, rather than struggle further and deepen the burrs. Perhaps this is the excuse I give myself to not act, not support, not back, not chant, not take to the streets. This fog has only grown thicker as the protests movements have moved closer and closer to home.

In response, I’ve recently become obsessed with learning about Gandhi. I’ve known he was an inspiration to Martin Luther King Junior and Mandela, who both led movements shifted the path of history towards one of greater justice. Yet, I never depend on my relationship with his thinking first hand. It surprised me to see how he was initially so keen on serving the British empire, how duty-bound he felt to support them in their time of need. How strict he was with himself to do what he believed was true.

The movie Gandhi which came out in 1982, paints him in a picture where he seemed to act for goodness or to support India’s liberation movement. What inspires me is that he saw his entire endeavor as seeking the truth. It’s still resolving for me, yet I’m beginning to understand the threads he makes between truth-seeking, seeing the other as the self, and nonviolent noncooperation.

Gandhi’s first experiments in communal living started after reading Unto This Last by Ruskin. which is essentially an economic and political argument the crux of which is equal pay for all work and free schooling for all people. It led him to make some conclusions about self-sufficiency and to start building what later became known as his first ashram in South Africa. I’m finding that proto villages, eco makerspaces, earth ships, hacker farms, rural co-living spaces, spiritual permaculture hubs and other similar type spaces have been inspiring me more in these last years. Although considering them as a social alternative seems to lead to a strange future where educated, upper-middle-class and tech-savvy people flee cities to take the place of the rural people who just left the farms for a better 20th-century life. The continuation of that trend seems to pave the way to a dystopian survivalist version of the future with micro governments (mobs?) rule principalities.

Gandhi was nationalistic, and he believed in an India ruled by its population. The injustice of the British empire was apparent to him. What are the fundamental injustices behind so many of our modern-day protest movements? Growing financial inequality, corruption — which to me can be seen as related to inequality in that it’s a sort of jealousy described as a call towards fairness and potential ecological collapse. To my mind, these are caught in a quagmire. It’s a bit like an escalating feud. Power leads to economic and political gain at the expense of people and environment. Then in the process of removing the offensive force, people desire the same power and economic gains at the expense – yet again – of the natural world and quite possibly abusing another class of people.

Seek not greater wealth, but simpler pleasure; not higher fortune, but deeper felicity.

-Mahatma Gandhi

Gandhi had an interesting idea about the ethic of non-stealing. His perspective is that if you took any more than you needed for essential survival, you’re taking from someone else’s survival and hence qualified as theft and thus ate and owned very little. This sort of subsistence living may not be aspirational for many, and it may not need to be. There are smart people making arguments of abundance and wealth, for instance:

“Wealth isnâ€™t about taking something from somebody elseâ€”itâ€™s about creating abundance for the world.”
-Naval Ravikant

Image result for the world has enough for everyone need but not everyone greed

“TheÂ world has enough for everyone’s needs,Â but not everyone’s greed,”

Mahatma Gandhi

In different times of my life, I have dreamt of different dreams. One is of exploring the origins of reality and galaxies with a Dyson Sphere powering our class II civilization. The other is one where I realize how little I truly need to be happy, and enjoy life building paper microscopes with my hypothetical children.

I am full of questions and doubts about what a beautiful way to live is, and I am open to living those questions as honestly as I can. What I loved about learning about Gandhi’s life is how commitments he made were like steps on a ladder. That a vow was solemn and that once he made it, you could trust it as much as you could trust a sturdy ladder leaning on a cliff face. That Gandhi’s exploration of metaphysical truth led to an in-world reality that others could rely on him for as much as they could rely on gravity.

Gandhi’s belief in Ahimsa – non-violence to any living thing – led him to a practice of humbling one’s self. It’s in this way he saw himself in all others.
Ahimsa is related to how Gandhi practiced non-violent non-cooperation, otherwise known as Satyagraha which is comprised of these principles:

Nonviolence (ahimsa)
Truth â€” this includes honesty, but also means living fully for what is true, and agreeing with it
Not stealing
Non-possession or nor owning (not the same as being poor)
Body-labor or bread-labor
Not being afraid
Equal respect for all religions
Fighting withÂ boycottsÂ (not spending or buying from those who are a problem)
Others as well, check the article above
To wrap up. Our systems are broken for the people and the planet. Protests movements are sprouting up requesting change at many levels and in many countries (I include the rise of the right wing and fascist political developments as a form of protest, asking to be heard). Questions about minimalism retreating and/or the possibility of abundance value creation for ever more people pop up. These ideas in turn disturb the desire for abnegation – although there may be a path related to value creation as a humble act of service and not an ego driven vehicle and/or expression of self into world.

Here are some thoughts on protests and the future of some aspects of economics and politics. I would love to hear reflections.

Continuing my hunt for my adventures in truth, I’m staying on the Gandhi reading list, next onto Tolstoy!

What do our virtual environments bring out of us?

I had a dream a few nights before 2020. I dreamt about the early web and how inspiring it was. It could have been a fluke that I hit puberty while web was still shiny? Or was there something really different about source code you could read/steal, finding a friend with a static IP address and hosting our own Movable Type instance. I still recall meeting people on IRC and waiting 30 mins to download a .wav file of some poorly played guitar music. The low quality staticy music of Smelly Cat made me feel like a modern day Alexander Bell. It was magical.

I saved those files, I saved our chats. Our connection felt special and meaningful. Connecting from my basement room in Michigan to friends in New Zealand was like opening your eyes for the first time, grainy and low resolution, yet still in a strange way so much more real than what passes for connection on social media today.

What’s changed? Speed, resolution, availability, mobile phones. This article claims that the 2010’s have broken our perception of time, in part due to the non-chronological newsfeed algorithms twitter and facebook rolled out. Perhaps.

In my life, I confess, I was sold on the rise of the self, the idea of the influencer, the personal brand. I was told careers are dead and that to be safe I had to be famous. The more followers you have the more successful. That I had to have my own URL, that I needed to get on each social media platform early and post often to make sure that I got followers. Somehow it fell under “need” rather than “want”. That this is simply how to get projects going, this is how the “work” is these days. I believed it and it helped to dim the magic of the internet for me.

All is not lost though, I get fleeting feelings of connection when I post deeper content or make requests. I recently asked for book recommendations and was surprised to find some people still respond with insight there. Twitter as well. Today I had an incredible video chat with my friend Cesar in Hong Kong over 3G as he biked home, a technology which would have been mind blowing in 2002.

This makes me wonder if there’s a lot of beauty and magic //still// happening online. That perhaps all is not lost, and that there is a greater amount of it on Minecraft, in discord servers, or in decentralized communities. What if my online experience is a mirror of myself and I’m getting out of it what I’m putting in. There is a diversity of people online. If I contain multitudes, what about the multitudes themselves?

My friend Pavel and I had a pokey question about the value of creating content that no one reads, that’s harder to scale with a tweet, that’s more than 140 characters long, that has no picture attached, that doesn’t even have a singing emoji or gif.

Let’s take creation VS consumption. The tendency online for me is to trigger conversation rather than contribute. The tendency for me is to scroll or to go from one wiki link or article to the next, rather than to sit and contemplate or draw and share.

Architecture shapes reality, that’s for sure. Having a blog //is// very different than posting on facebook, that’s for sure. So it seems to me that first I need to determine first is who I want to be online and to find the enabling spaces that support that.

Who would you like to be online?

Here’s my commitment to trying to be who I want to be and sharing as I go.

Background:
The decade of the 2020’s is marked by a series of compounding crises, the coronavirus pandemic, intensifying climactic events due to the climate crisis, and, relatedly, the increase in socio-political disorder. Humor, Character Strengths and Deliberate Rumination For Social Entrepreneurs in Lebanon in Crisis
Factors Contributing to Post Traumatic Growth for Social Entrepreneurs in Crisis
Background: In 2020 the world was challenged by a global pandemic. In Lebanon, the addition of an economic collapse and a major explosion in the capital city brought acute stressors, triggering migration ideation. In this study, we identify factors that support social entrepreneur’s access to post traumatic growth (PTG) by analyzing resilience and character strengths within an entrepreneurship training program in Beirut. 
Methods:  Over the course of Dec 2020 and April 2021 we gathered 21 hours and a half interviews with Lebanese social entrepreneurs going through an entrepreneurship training program, all of whom were living in Lebanon and experienced the August 2020 Beirut port explosion. Alongside these interviews we gathered a set of qualitative data including pre-post assessments of Character Strengths (VIA), Post Traumatic Growth Inventory (PTG-I), Intrusive and Deliberate Rumination (EERI), Entrepreneurial Intent (EI), Resilience (BRCS) and the Impact of Event - Revised (IES-R). Correlations were identified with factors that support PTG and social entrepreneurial ideation. 
Results: Character Strengths are correlated with PTG and there are validated methods for reliably developing strengths of character. One highly leverable strength is humor, and one way humor can support growth is by preventing helplessness. 
Conclusions: While each person’s life journey is unique, we have identified that social entrepreneurship ideation is promoted by prior traumatic experiences if followed by opportunities and support for growth. Traumatic experiences are inescapable in life, and the opportunity educators and trainers have is to understand how to shift the trauma response curve towards growth. Deliberate Rumination, thinking and reflecting about one’s life circumstances can happen spontaneously and importantly they can be nurtured by incorporating them into group facilitations for training programs and schools. 
Implications:  The results of this study increases an understanding of the complex decision making individuals face in a crisis, and offers insights into the factors which support posttraumatic growth and social entrepreneurship. We hope the results of this paper inspire facilitators to incorporate humor, positive structured conversation and to enliven their program with character development.

Overview of Data and Background Knowledge
After a threatening situation, animals and humans respond in a variety of ways. Initially described by Walter Cannon (Cannon, W. B. 1915) as the Fight or Flight response, the theory has since then been adapted by Dr. Stephen Porges into Polyvagal theory (Porges 2009). This model now includes freezing as an alternative response, and attempts to correlate stress responses to neurohormonal responses. In the face of a situation in which no options seem viable, an individual can either choose to fight, flee (flight) or freeze. We will be using these three types of responses as a framing for potential ways our interviewees responded to the Beirut Blast.

In 2011, Martin Seligman (Seligman 2011) made the hypothesis that PERMA (Positive Emotion, Engagement, Relationships, Meaning, and Accomplishment) comprises well-being, and argues that the model is helpful for measurement as well as for application (Seligman 2018).

Data validity questions. 
We initially hypothesized that there would be a correlation between CS prepost (Character Strengths Difference in average scores assessed before/after the blast) and Post Traumatic Growth. While there seems to be a slight correlation between CS prepost and PTGI - Appreciation (.33 p-val .14) we cannot at this time with our limited data make any strong statements about Character Strength changes before/after an explosion and PTGI. One factor could be that the time frame for the post test was taken over a 3 month period (December - March 2020) and it might be interesting to study a progression of changes rather than comparing pre and post. Growth takes time and measuring over an extended period confuses the data. Also, assessing people earlier, and therefore closer to the period of the traumatic event may not have left time to metabolize the experience while people who filled in the assessment later have had more opportunities. Another bias that may be influencing the data is potentially the types of people who submit forms early compared to those who wait may also capture proactive people early in the recovery process and procrastinators later in their process. Rather than adding another factor to control for procrastination, I propose future assessments to include deadlines for inclusion into the dataset, or to include time of receipt as an influencing factor.

Background: The movement of Palestinians in the occupied Palestinian territories is restricted by bureaucratic and physical obstacles. To date, no studies have examined the barriers that Palestinian medical students face in accessing hospitals for clinical training. The objectives of this study were to characterize these barriers and understand how they affect Palestinian students’ medical education and quality of life.
Methods: Convenience sampling was used to recruit 4th-6th year medical students from Al-Quds University to participate in focus group discussions. A total of 36 students participated in the discussions. Transcripts of the discussions were coded to identify major themes.
Results: Palestinian medical students expressed facing numerous challenges during their clinical training. Students emphasized the difficulties of obtaining permits to train at Jerusalem hospitals, including arbitrary permit rejections and long wait times. Significant delays, searches, and mistreatment at checkpoints during their commute to hospitals were particularly burdensome. The majority of students who participated in the focus groups felt that their education and quality of life had been strongly negatively affected by their experience trying to access hospital training sites.
Conclusions: Our findings suggest that medical students living and studying in the occupied Palestinian territories receive sub-optimal training due to ambiguous permit rules, barriers at checkpoints, and the psychological burden of the process. These results highlight the impact that military occupation has on the education and quality of life of Palestinian medical students in a setting in which there is regular violence and many health indicators are already poor.

ABSTRACT
This study documents the perceptions and experiences of immigrant women and men in the US related to female genital cutting (FGC). This paper examines the effects of migration on these perceptions, with the goal of op- timizing health services and informing public policy to support women who have undergone FGC. 1. Introduction
The World Health Organization defines “female genital mutilation” as a procedure involving removal of or injury to the female genital organs for non-medical reasons (WHO, 2008). More than 200 million women and girls have undergone female genital cutting (FGC) globally, with an additional 3 million girls under the age of 18 “at risk” each year (WHO, 2008). While the practice varies widely, much research has shown that women who undergo FGC face negative health and social consequences (Ball, 2008; Utz-Billing and Kentenich, 2008; WHO, 2008). FGC is classified into different types (WHO, 2014): Type 1 in- volves removing part or all of the clitoris or the prepuce. Type 2, in- volves removing part or all of the clitoris and labia minora, with or without the labia majora. Type 3, called infibulation or pharaonic, in- volves removing part or all of the external genitalia and narrowing the vaginal orifice by reapproximating the labia minora and/or labia ma- jora. Type 4 encompasses all other harmful procedures to the genitalia
for non-medical reasons. The term sunna, meaning “prophetic tradi- tion”, is generally used to describe non-infibulating forms of FGC.
1.1. The United States
In 1996, the United States Congress banned FGC. In 2000, Brigham and Women's Hospital's African Women's Health Center used census data to estimate that 228,000 girls living in the US had either under- gone or were at risk of FGC. This represented approximately a 35% increase from the 1990 census data (Nour et al., 2006). More recent estimates tell us that 513,000 girls under the age of 18 in the US are now at risk of FGC—more than three times the number in 1990 (Goldberg et al., 2016). Researchers attribute this increase in estimated number of girls at risk to increased migration from FGC-practicing countries as well as a change in the estimation technique to include both first and second generation girls (Goldberg et al., 2016).

1.2. The persistence of FGC
Various reasons have been cited for the persistence of FGC including its role as a rite of passage, the preservation of chastity, ensuring marriageability, religious requirements, hygiene, and enhancing sexual pleasure for men (Nour, 2008; WHO, 2008; Mackie and LeJeune, 2009). A systematic review of 21 studies of members of communities that practiced FGC but reside in Western countries pointed to six key factors underpinning FGC: cultural traditions, sexual morals, marriageability, religion, health benefits, and male sexual enjoyment (Berg and Dension., 2013). In almost all the studies included in that review, FGC was referred to as a meaningful and valued cultural practice linked to honor and the preservation of chastity, enforced through community mechanisms. The current study seeks to avoid oversimplifying the practice and immigrants’ perceptions of it by presenting complex and often contrasting views among a diverse set of immigrant women and men.
1.3. Community based research in immigrant populations
Some research has examined perceptions and experiences of FGC in African diasporic communities in the United States (Akinsulure-Smith, 2014; Connor et al., 2016; Johnson et al., 2009; McNeely and Jong, 2016). A qualitative study among 30 female Somali refugees in Min- nesota found that participants endorsed negative attitudes towards FGC, largely secondary to health consequences as well as a new un- derstanding that FGC is not sanctioned religiously (Connor et al., 2016). A qualitative study among 13 Somali refugees in Colorado found that all participants reported having changed their views on FGC after moving, often due to education, migration, and dissociation of the practice from religious beliefs (McNeely and Jong, 2016). Lastly, a study among Somali immigrant women about their challenging FGC- related healthcare experiences in the US emphasized the importance of engaging in community-based participatory research using mixed- methods to build trust-based networks and actively engage community members in the research process (Johnson et al., 2009).
There is also research on FGC among African diasporic communities outside the United States (Abdulcadir et al., 2016; Jaldesa and Abdi 2014; Vloeberghs et al. 2012). A study in Nairobi found that Ethiopian immigrants viewed FGC as a tool to curb female sexuality and enforce fixed gender roles upon women; those researchers called for commu- nity-based education programming involving religious leaders, NGOs, government ministries, and other actors (Jaldesa and Abdi 2014). A study of immigrants from Sub-Saharan Africa residing in Hamburg, Germany found that most immigrants speak out for the abandonment of FGC, but that there is a solid minority who maintain either positive or indifferent attitudes towards the practice (Behrendt, 2011). Other stu- dies also reflect this overwhelming rejection of FGC after immigration (Johnsdotter et al., 2007), while some studies delineate certain groups of immigrants that may tend to have more traditional views towards the practice, such as males, older generations, and new arrivals (Morison et al., 2004). There are differing views on the kind of effect the process of migration has on the viewpoints of immigrants on FGC. One fra- mework might suggest that immigrants may cling more strongly to cultural norms such as FGC in an effort to retain their cultural identity, while an opposing theory might suggest that immigrants are more likely to abandon a practice such as FGC in the process of assimilation (Berry, 1997).
1.4. Men's perspectives
Few studies in the US have explored the varied perspectives of men on FGC. A recent study in Somalia indicated that 96% of men preferred to marry women who have undergone FGC but that women were less likely than men to support FGC (Almroth et al., 2001). Similarly, a study in Oslo found that Somali immigrant men were more likely than

However, a qualitative study in the US found that male Somali refugees were aware of FGC-related morbidities and did not support the practice, while many women seemed supportive (Johnson-Agbakwu et al., 2014). More detailed comparisons of men and women's views in the US are needed to determine how perceptions of FGC itself and FGC-tar- geted interventions might be similar or different across gender lines.
1.5. Objectives
This study documents the FGC-related perceptions and experiences of immigrant women and men in Boston, Massachusetts, and attempts to understand the effect of migration on these perceptions, with the larger goal of optimizing health services and informing public policy to support women who have undergone FGC. Our study is unique in considering not only the views of women who have undergone FGC (not simply all women from FGC-practicing countries), but also the views of immigrant men from the same communities. Furthermore, this study investigates the nature of FGC-related communication between mem- bers of the diaspora and relatives in their communities of origin across Africa and the Middle East—an important facet of the subject that past studies have not investigated.
2. Methods
We designed a qualitative study consisting of individual interviews in Boston, Massachusetts, with immigrant women who experienced FGC themselves and immigrant men with family members who had experienced FGC, to explore their views on the practice and the dis- course surrounding it. We report our qualitative research in accordance with the COREQ criteria (Tong et al., 2007).
2.1. Ethics, consent, and permissions
This study was approved by the Brigham and Women's Hospital Institutional Review Board (IRB). Informed consent was obtained verbally and participants were provided with a study information sheet. No compensation or incentives were given to study participants.
2.2. Topic guide
The topic guides for the interviews were created by the researchers based on gaps in the literature related to the perspectives and experi- ences of people in the US who immigrated from communities where FGC has been practiced. The topic guides, one tailored to men and the other to women [Appendix A] were reviewed for content, clarity, and cultural sensitivity by Harvard Medical School faculty of both African and Middle Eastern descent. The topic guides consisted of three sec- tions: participants’ personal views on FGC and the cultural and social factors that have affected their views; personal experiences with FGC and its long-term effects; and perceptions of community views of the practice both in their countries of origin and in the US diaspora.
2.3. Sampling
Convenience sampling was used to recruit both women and men living in Boston who had immigrated from communities where FGC has been practiced, including parts of Egypt, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Ghana, Mali, Nigeria, Somalia, Sudan, and the United Arab Emirates. Inclusion cri- teria included women and men above 18 years of age who immigrated from these countries and now live in Boston. For women, it was ne- cessary that they themselves had undergone FGC. For men, it was ne- cessary that they had a family member who had undergone FGC. Individuals who were below 18 years of age or women who had not undergone FGC were excluded.

A 30-year-old Somali woman explained that, in the context of exploring marriage options, discussions around having undergone FGC often serve as a means of discussing virginity, an important quality to her in the larger sociopolitical context of marriage and desirability.

[...] In the stories I had heard and the books I read, it [painful sex] can make the woman hate the man. I didn't want her to resent me so I said take it easy and slowly. 4. Discussion
Our study sheds light on the views and experiences of immigrant men and women in Boston, Massachusetts originating from a variety of communities where FGC is practiced. Participants expressed a range of rationales for the practice of FGC, and many questioned the validity of these rationales and the continuation of the practice, especially in its most severe forms. Notably, this is among the few studies in which men of the diaspora in the United States have been interviewed on the topic

of FGC. Most male participants strongly opposed the practice due to its effects on their wives' sexual and childbirth experiences. Religion seemed to play a role in participants’ views, both for and against the practice. Participants also cited immigration and education as having significant effects on the changing views regarding the continuation of the practice. Furthermore, many participants considered themselves capable of playing an important role in influencing the discourse around the practice of FGC in their home communities.
Both the Christians and Muslims in our study cited religion as an important factor in both the continuation and curbing of the practice of FGC. While the Quran does not mention FGC, and it is not practiced in most Muslim-majority countries, many Muslim participants said they grew up with the understanding that Islam mandated the practice. Nevertheless, our participants also cited religion, religious leaders, and religious institutions as instrumental in shaping their own views and views in their home communities against FGC. In Johnsdotter's study of Somali women living in Sweden, participants were especially opposed to pharaonic circumcision, as they had developed the belief that it was contrary to basic Islamic principles (Johnsdotter, 2003). Many of our participants admitted that they would not have been able to abandon the practice had they not learned through education, and in many cases immigration, that FGC was not religiously compulsory. Thus, the campaigns of religious leaders and institutions against FGC seem to play a critical role in influencing community perspectives on FGC.
The term sunna, meaning “according to the tradition of the Prophet Muhammad”, was generally used by our participants to refer to Type I FGC, but can be used to describe any non-infibulating form of FGC, considered ‘less severe’ than Type III. In some countries such as Somalia, Type I FGC has been harder to eradicate than Type III, termedpharaonic, as the latter carries a non-Islamic name that people seem more ready to question (The World Bank, 2004; Gele et al., 2012). In a few prior studies, including one in Somalia and another among Somali refugees in the US, some women expressed a preference for Type I FGC, seeing it as a safe alternative to Type III for both health and religious reasons (Fried et al., 2013; McNeely and Jong, 2016; Connor et al., 2016). While the Somali women in Fried's study had received unequi- vocal messages from the campaigns of religious leaders and institutions that the practice of Type III FGC was un-Islamic and so had started opposing it, many had received conflicting messages regarding Type I FGC, hearing that it was either prohibited, a religious mandate, or optional (Fried et al., 2013). These mixed messages are reflected in our own study population of men and women living in the US, who were overwhelmingly against the practice of FGC, especially Type III, with some participants having more equivocal views on Type I.
The men in our study collectively took a stand against FGC, espe- cially due to its impact on their wives' health and sexual lives and concern that their daughters might suffer the same. In a study of West African immigrants in New York City, men were found to be as knowledgeable about the health consequences of FGC as women, though with a less nuanced understanding, and were just as likely as women to reject the practice (Akinsulure-Smith and Chu, 2017). An- other study exploring Gambian men's knowledge found that only a minority of men were aware of FGC health consequences, but those who understood its negative impact on the health and well-being of girls and women were very willing to play a role in its prevention (Kaplan et al., 2013). A systematic review of twenty studies on the role of men in abandonment of FGC found that education level was one of the most important indicators for men's support for abandonment of the practice (Varol et al., 2015). Both social obligation and a lack of dia- logue between men and women on the issue were identified as barriers to abandonment.
In one study, men in a Somali community in the US expressed that they play key roles in explaining their own socio-cultural contexts to American healthcare providers and as advocates for their wives in a foreign healthcare system (Johnson-Agbakwu et al., 2014). Similarly, several men in our own study facilitated their wives' access to
healthcare providers at the African Women's Health Center after having negative experiences with physicians with limited awareness of the practice of FGC. Both the men and women in our study discussed the intimate roles of men as supportive husbands, both sexually and emo- tionally, particularly at the time of their wives' first sexual experiences, which many participants described as painful. Most profoundly, many male participants explored their current and potential roles as ad- vocates against the practice of FGC. While they admitted that they had generally thought of the practice as a “women's issue,” many had begun to feel that men could play a vital role in curbing the practice in their communities. The men we interviewed believed that they had a parti- cular duty to raise awareness in their families and their communities about the physical and emotional harm FGC can cause and spoke of their roles in dissuading their family and community members from continuing the practice.
In our study, the perceived role of immigration in influencing par- ticipants’ views against FGC cannot be ignored. Many Muslim partici- pants explained that, due to exposure to Muslims immigrating from countries where FGC was not practiced, immigrants felt more ready to question and ultimately dismiss the perceived religious origins of the practice. In this way, immigration seems to provide a space where people of different diasporic communities interact and exchange ideas, a phenomenon supported by prior studies (McNeely and Jong, 2016; Berggren et al., 2006). According to the “modified stages of change” theory, Shell-Duncan proposes that people abandon the practice of FGC when they find a motivation to do so and when their social context supports, promotes, or at least accepts abandonment, such as in the setting of immigration (Shell-Duncan and Herniund, 2006). A study examining the temporal effect of immigration on attitudes towards FGC found that immigration to Britain from a younger age appeared to be associated with abandonment of FGC and changes in the more tradi- tional beliefs that underpin it (Morison et al., 2004). While we did not demonstrate the same findings as recent immigrants also shared nega- tive views of FGC, our sample size is also small and unlikely to be able to demonstrate such a difference. One theory relevant to this could be the migration selection hypothesis, which posits that those who migrate tend to be wealthier, educated and from urban settings, factors known to be associated with reduced support for FGC (Ortensi et al., 2015). However, our study population had a large proportion of refugees and asylum seekers and did not represent a disproportionately wealthy group.
One framework to understand the abandonment of FGC is the social convention theory of interdependent decision-making. As Mackie and LeJeune describe, FGC is a community practice that traditionally fa- cilitated social belonging and marriageability (Mackie and LeJeune, 2009). Therefore, ending the practice cannot only be an individual endeavor, but requires the entire community, starting with a critical mass of its most influential members, to collectively and publicly abandon it. Remarkably, as the authors emphasize, “The underlying moral norm of care for one's children, which motivates the decision to practice FGM/C can also inspire communities to reconsider the prac- tice” (Mackie and LeJeune, 2009, page 2).
As all our participants were aware of US laws outlawing FGC, we asked them specifically about the illegal practice commonly known as “vacation cutting,” in which immigrants are said to attempt to sustain the practice of FGC by returning to their countries of origin with their daughters for the purpose of having them undergo FGC (Goldberg et al., 2016). Based on our qualitative data, immigrants from multiple coun- tries of origin had heard of the practice but did not know of any such cases in their families or communities and found it hard to believe that it was possible, particularly given the legal consequences. There are no reliable sources of data on the prevalence of this practice in the United States (Nour, 2015; Goldberg et al., 2016). New laws are being pro- posed in the US to target these communities to address this practice; however, caution will have to be exercised in the enforcement of these laws so as to avoid racial profiling, especially as the practice has not

As Johnsdotter et al. write in their qualitative study that found firm rejection of all forms of FGC among Ethiopian and Eritrean immigrants in Sweden, “A societal structure prepared to deal with suspected cases of FGC with a high level of alertness should be combined with a healthy skeptical attitude to- ward exaggerations of risk estimates” (Johnsdotter et al., 2007, page 114).
To our knowledge, this is the first study to specifically explore the current and potential roles of diasporic communities in engaging with the perceptions and practices of FGC in their communities of origin. Participants' responses were mixed; many believed that they already had some influence in dissuading their family and friends from having FGC performed on their daughters. Others had not considered it pre- viously, but affirmed that their participation in this study would inspire them to call their relatives in their countries of origin to discuss the practice. Mackie's social norms theory is interesting to consider in this context: are members of the diaspora influential enough to impact perception and practice in their countries of origin (Mackie and LeJeune, 2009)? More research is required to investigate this question. Based on our findings, research and initiatives that target FGC should incorporate the exchange of ideas and experiences between immigrant communities and their communities of origin, while paying attention to local efforts in communities where FGC is currently practiced.
4.1. Implications and future directions
Our study has several implications. Our participants describe per- sonal and communal change that they attribute to multiple factors in- cluding education, immigration, changing social pressures, and im- proved religious literacy, all of which can be used to promote and support change in practice. Our study also highlights a need for more targeted involvement of already motivated male members of the com- munity in the effort to curb the practice of FGC. Our preliminary ex- ploration of the role of members of the diaspora provides some support for initiatives that would involve emigrants in the effort to curb the practice in home countries. Further research should be conducted to study the efficacy of this approach. Although our study is limited geo- graphically to Boston, Massachusetts, our findings do not support the fear that vacation cutting might be common among US immigrants. We should therefore exercise caution in our promotion of legislation and clinical practices that target this fear.
4.2. Limitations
This study is subject to several limitations. While participants were forthcoming with personal information, the topic of FGC can be sensi- tive not only emotionally, but also legally; it is possible that due to the heavy bias and strict laws in the United States against FGC, participants who looked upon the practice more favorably might have been less forthcoming about topics like vacation cutting or their personal or community views on the topic. Our participants are not intended as a representative sample of the immigrant population in the US, and it is entirely possible that the views of our participants, who presented to the African Women's Health Center or other community centers where they were recruited, might differ from the views of other members of their communities. Additionally, those willing to discuss FGC in a study may represent different attitudes than those who would not choose to participate. Finally, in addition to being a benefit, focusing on im- migrants from multiple countries in our study may mask trends and themes that might be more specific to a specific community or country.
5. Conclusion
Unlike previous studies that focused on only one community/ country of origin, this study documents the perceptions and experiences of immigrant men and women in Boston, Massachusetts, from a wide
variety of communities where FGC is practiced. Many participants questioned the rationales behind FGC in their own lives and felt strongly against the continuation of the practice of FGC. This change in opinion, described by our participants as taking place on both the personal and community levels, was most frequently attributed to education and immigration. Our study provides strong support for the inclusion of men, religious leaders, and immigrants in FGC-related ef- forts. Changing views in the diaspora could play a significant role in affecting opinions and practices in contexts where FGC is prevalent. Finally, none of the participants personally knew of anyone who per- formed vacation cutting, calling into question the concern that vacation cutting might be common among US immigrants. We should therefore exercise caution in our promotion of legislation and clinical practices that target this fear.
